description: The former Charity School was constructed in 1793, by Obodiah Legrew, who also purchased the adjoining no.24 Church Street, part of the surviving earlier 18th century range, to create a small cottage for the School Mistress.

events.name: Open Access
events.notes:
Visitors can arrive at any time during the opening hours.

There may be queues at busy times.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The Charity School was constructed in 1784, by Obodiah Legrew, who also purchased the adjoining no.24 Church Street, part of the surviving earlier 18th century range, to create a small cottage for the School Mistress.

The Charity School is a simply designed front-gabled building, constructed of yellow brick with red rubbed brick voussoirs, a single central door flanked by tall sash window and a statue of a girl holding a prayer book/bible in a central arched recess set into the gable. The construction of no.24 is not clear, though it is faced in brick and has replacement casement windows on the first floor.  The buildings were extended to the rear in 1827.

location.address: Charity School Hall (next door to 24 Church Street), N9 9DU

name: Former Edmonton Girls' Charity School
